results.title: Special Role of Teacher, Multi-Cultural Soc.(Keynote)(TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Special Role of the Teacher in the Multicultural Society”.
‘The special role of the teacher in a multi-cultural society’ : a conference at S.C.V.Rushden (Keynote address). Keynote address by Lorna Lippman, Director of Community Relations Bureau. Introduction by D.D.Taylor, Dean. Welcoming address by Dr. P.J.Wisch, Principal.

results.title: Frame looms
results.creator_credit: John Gray, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Weaving”.
A simple instructional film on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. Attractive woven patterns can be made on any type of frame.

results.title: Horses
results.brief_description: Two girls go cross-country-hacking. The film explains preparation, brushing, bridling, and saddling. Good introductory film to beginners and non-riders.

results.title: Down River
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Gippsland”.
For some, floods are a disaster, for others a necessary lifegiving event. The quite different ecology of the riverland is explored in this Gippsland Victoria series, which gives an insight into the Gippsland region and the full scope of natural phenomenon

results.title: High country
results.creator_credit: George Miller, Geoff Burrowes and Yenan Productions
results.brief_description: A group of amateur horsemen cross Victoria’s Great Dividing Range using a little frequented track. Shows without commentary, the grandeur and mystique of the region. Music by Mario Mills and Jon English

results.title: Make Believe Play (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Structuring Play in the Infant School Series No.4”.
Shows children’s play with paint, crayons, scrap, collage and dressing-up materials, that involves children in making and pretending. It shows the development from spontaneous play to a structured play situation

results.title: Safety in your hands
results.creator_credit: John Fitzgerald, Edwin Scragg, Jill Robb and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
This 1974 film examines the responsibility of each worker for their own safety in the workplace. The film focuses particularly on protection of hands and eyes in industrial settings, showing a variety of machines operated by people. It demonstrates how untidiness, inattention, overconfidence and failure to use safety precautions such as safety glasses when operating these machines can lead to accidents. Footage of industrial workplaces is interspersed with footage of everyday accidents similarly caused by mess, distraction and overconfidence.

Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Play safe
results.creator_credit: Dennis Hill Productions, Keith Gow, John Morris, Education Dept of S A and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The fun of swimming and participating in water sports can be spoiled unless basic safety rules and techniques are known, practised and used. This comprehensive water safety film covers all aspects from drown-proofing to the use of life-jackets, to a full illustration of the Royal Life Saving Award technique of safe non-contact rescue. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis Hill Productions, Keith Gow, John Morris, Education Dept of S A and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: The Last coastline
results.creator_credit: G Turney-Smith, Jack Hume, Arkaba Films and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: In 1802, Captain Matthew Flinders explored and charted the last unknown coastline on Earth. We see this magnificent coastline as Flinders saw it, recreating his journey with the help of the record in his ship’s log. The coastline is that of Eyre Peninsula, South Australia - a coastline that has been barely touched by man. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
